title: Bönidal, Lönning, Lunnasting
derivation: Bönidal- bœn - as in 'bœnhús' -house of prayer; dalr (ON) a dale, valley, possibly patches of arable land (Jakobsen, p34 & p131)
poem:
Onnly bird-sang noo

Stirleens in squadrons bear uncans
fae barn tae shimley: föls o da air
at haem i da waas. Alang aeshins,
crusty wi aald man's baerd,
a Robbie Cuddie jinks, aaber
ta shaa you roond. At da shore,
böds an noosts mulder.
Draa dee in ta da fire fir a yarn;
dan, whin he's faa'n in ess,
twartree göd wirds.

Only bird-song now

Starlings in squadrons bear news
from barn to chimney: birds of the air
at home in the walls. Along gable-edge,
crusty with lichen,
a wren jinks, keen
to show you round. At the shore,
lodges and boat-shelters crumble.
Draw up to the fire for story-telling;
then, once it's collapsed in ash,
a brief prayer.

title: Sannik, Sweening Voe (Inhabited from c1850 until late 20th century)
derivation: Sandwik: Sandr - sand (O.N.); vik- inlet, small bay (O.N.); (Jakobsen, p93 & p115)
poem:
Da lang view

A boat's oars hark ta Swining Voe:
freends, unlippened, wi a sprickle o mackreel.
Shö laeves da hirdin fir damoarn,
bakes scones, wöshes up da laem;
nivver dips her, staands owre dem
till dey'r stappit - 'tak een, tak twa!'
Her days here ir numbered.
Foo lang afore da taft feels
her weicht fir a hidmost time?

The long view

A boat's oars whisper to Swining Voe:
friends, unexpected, with a few wriggling mackerel.
She leaves the gleaning for tomorrow,
bakes oatcakes, washes the dishes;
never pulls up a chair, stands over them
till they're stuffed - 'have one, have two!'
Her days here are numbered.
How long before the thwart feels
her weight for a final time?

title: Da Fain (or Fern), Grönafirth, Nort Nesting
derivation: Da Fain / possibly from Fēna, O.N. - a fen, a quagmire (Jakobsen, p13)
poem:
On a nicht o distress

Da lino lifts as Faider wins
fae da lammie hoose, drookit;
hings up his oilskins; winders
foo dey'll manage trowe anidder winter.
Aald Daa draas him in ta da stove, blyde
he's lang haem fae da sea. Midder fills
da kettle, spreads scones fir supper;
kens nane 'll come in aboot da nicht.

Steep stair tae da laft:
bairns prammed in,
happy as a yalloo door.
On a coorse nicht, flans i da lum,
dey poo da twilt owre dir lugs.

On a stormy night

The lino lifts as Dad returns
from the lambs' barn, soaked to the skin;
hangs up his oilskins; wonders
how they'll manage through another winter.
Grandad draws in to the stove, glad
He's no longer at sea. Mum fills
the kettle, spreads oatcakes for supper;
knows no neighbour will come along tonight.

Steep stair to attic:
children squeezed in
happy as a yellow door.
On a stormy night, sudden gusts in the chimney,
they pull the quilt over their ears.

title: Ockran, Aeshaness
derivation: Okren - akr (O.N.) corn-field; 'á Økrun' - name of a Faroese village (Jakobsen, p19)
poem:
Afore da factor darkened da door, dey tocht

whaar better apön a simmer's day dan here:
quiet, shaltered, lyin i da face o da sun?
wir ain mill-burn at nivver rins dry;
at da geo, hit's a frush owre da banks
wir ponies apö da hill; an wir mödow, up tae
da hochs in a ön o haet, waitin fir da sye
i da yerd we'll hae desses an skrews
ta see wis trowe winter
wir girnal foo, da barn forbye.

Before the factor darkened the door, they thought

where better on a summer's day than here:
quiet, sheltered, lying in the face of the sun?
our own mill-burn that never runs dry
at the inlet, it's a gush over the cliffs
our ponies on the hill; and our meadow, knee-deep
in sultry heat, waiting for the scythe
in the yard we'll have hay-stacks and oat-stacks
to see us through winter
the meal-chest full, the barn as well.

title: Saeter o Ennisfirt, Gunnister Voe, Nortmaven
poem:
Hooses wi lang memories

Atween Birka Vird an da voe
de'r little grund ta wirk
but nae want o soleed granite.
Dis hoose 'll be tellin hits tale
lang eftir fock seek a aesier life:
whin dey trade dat view ta Foula
fir mair laand, fir Lerrick's lanes,
fir New Zealand or Australia.

Hooses draem o faemlies,
a scry o bairns, wyshin apö da line,
a mill-steyn dirlin.

Houses with long memories

Between summit and the inlet
there's little ground to cultivate
but no lack of solid granite.
This house will be telling its tale
long after folk seek an easier life:
when they trade that view to Foula
for more land, for Lerwick's lanes,
for New Zealand or Australia.

Houses dream of families,
a screed of children, washing on the line,
a mill-stone turning.

title: Nort Ham, Muckle Röe, Delting
derivation: Ham - O.N. hϙfn - haven, harbour (Jakobsen, p63)
poem:
On your ain

Granite gaevil ta da sun, on your ain here,
laek da erne on his skerry, or da swabi on his een.
Nane but dem ta share da view wi you.
Is yun a yowe or a rock apö da broo? Hit's laek
as if da hoose cam oot o da byörgs, unbidden:
steyn aawye, fine fir biggin - even da mill is
a wirk o art - but a trysht for horrow or ploo.
Sees-du yun boat makkin fir da shore -
whit tinks-du ir dey seekin?

On your own

Granite gable to the sun, on your own here,
like the sea-eagle on his stack, or the black-back on his.
Only them to share the view with you.
Is that a ewe or a rock on the slope? It's as if
the house emerged from the rocky outcrops, unbidden:
stone everywhere, fine for building - even the mill is
a work of art - but awkward for harrow or plough.
Do you see that boat approaching the shore -
what do you think they might want?

title: Upper Skōlla, Firth, Delting
derivation: Skōlla - ON shed, hut - farm name (Jacobsen, p96)
poem:
An ivery een vod noo

Pund o Löt, Peerie Löt, Muckle Löt an Holla,
Da Quilbigirts, Da Toptigirts, Da Newoose an Upper Skolla.
Da Bergens nixt ta Boanniehoose, Da Giltik an Da Rös,
Eftir dat Da Punds o Firt, nixt ta dat Da Crös.
Flugirt lies in owre da hill, Sandgyo is but lonnly,
Mungraclett lies in a blett, an da Vellen, breeds onnly.

title: Delting Disaster Memorial, Mossbank
poem:
Da Loard gies an da Loard taks

Firts Voe, 1900

In Delting, a black Yöl, wi dir haddock boats
foondered i da gale an naethin but döl.
Oot owre, at Mongreklett, a midder cöllies roond
her faiderless tings, hoids her tears.

At Lüt an Pund o Lüt da sun is near-bi-gyaan.
Da aald midder consoles da bride, da dochter.
Dey'r nae boadies ta murn; nedder o her man,
nor her faider nor her fowr bördly bridders.

The Lord gives and the Lord takes

Firths Voe, 1900

In Delting, a black Christmas, with their haddock boats
foundered in the gale and grief everywhere.
Beyond the point, at Mongreklett, a mother comforts
her fatherless little ones, hides her tears.

At Lüt and Pund o Lüt the sun is miserly.
The old mother consoles the bride, the daughter.
There are no bodies to mourn: neither of her husband,
nor her father nor her four strapping brothers.

title: Kellister, Sandness
derivation: Kellister - from Ketel-setr, ON personal name of homestead (Jakobsen, p152 & p94)
poem:
Hoose wi a view

De'r steyns aawye, haeps o dem - rönnies -
grund cleared ivver since da Neolithic.

Wir sheep can roam as far as da eye can see.
We keepit da gligg tae da byre - hit's haandy
but whittan a nyoagin wi da kye in winter.

You can gyet fysh at Dale: dat's a braa piece
ta traivel. Burrafirt, Bousta, Norby - tak your pick:
he's a vaege ta ony o dem. We need wir boat.

Wir fock is mövin awa: ta Snarraness.an Sannis.
Dey draem o Australia an New Zealand, tak
a steyn i dir pooch; but dey manna luik back.

House with a view

There are stones everywhere, heaps of them - rönnies -
ground cleared ever since the Neolithic.

Our sheep can roam as far as the eye can see.
We kept the aperture to the cowshed - it's handy
but what a moaning with the cows in winter.

You can get fish at Dale: that's a long distance
to walk. Burrafirth, Bousta, Norby - take your pick:
it's a journey to any of them. We need our boat.

Our folk are moving away: to Snarraness and Sandness.
They dream of Australia and New Zealand, take
a stone in their pocket; but they mustn't look back.

title: Foratwatt, Waas
derivation: Foratwatt - O.N. þveit- a parcel of land, farm name (Jakobsen, p110)
poem:
Hoose apö da heichts

A lanerly hoose wi backstories best foryat:
telegrams wi black aedges o men lost.
Shö'd tried New Zealand, but nivver settled,
tinkin her rigs better, her hoose mair haemly.
But dey wir nae bairns.
Shö could see dir shadows, knee-deep
in flooers, bringin da baess haem fae
da simmer hill; an in winter, slaedgin doon
da darkenin, foo o maddrim an skirls.

House on the hilltop

A lonely house with backstories best forgotten:
telegrams with black edges of men lost.
She'd tried New Zealand, but never settled,
thinking her fields better, her house more homely.
But there were no children.
She could see their shadows, knee-deep
in flowers, bringing the cattle home from
the summer hill; and in winter, sledging down
the darkening, full of hilarity and laughter.

title: Nort Ham, Sooth Havera
derivation: Havera - probably from O.N. hafr - billy goat; or man's name Hafr (Jakobsen, p122)
poem:
Simmer ask

Whittan a ghosts rinnin oot
an in: weemen kerryin peerie tings,
cugs o watter, lipperin kishies;
or men winnin back fae da far haaf
dug-tired fae rowin trowe a steekit stima,
feelin dir wye, trivvelin da Moder Dy.
I dir heads dey'r coontin dir blisseens
an maybe foo mony röfs ithin dis gadderie
'll need ta be taekit come hairst.

Summer mist

So many ghosts running out
and in: women carrying little children,
kegs of water, overflowing back-baskets;
or men returning from distant fishing grounds
dog-tired from rowing through dense mist,
feeling their way, gently sensing under-currents.
In their heads they're counting their blessings
and maybe how many roofs in this settlement
will need to be thatched come harvest.

title: Brenya, Fladdabister
derivation: Brenya ON brenna, burning of heather, woodland for farming (Jacobsen, p30)
poem:
Anunder da broo

whaar you see dimriv brackin owre da Bard
an da sun mövin roond bi Helliness;

whaar de'r nae better steyn fir biggin,
an plenty clos ta haand;

whaar stakes can be driven deep
in a green laand. But we möv on:

laeve wan mizzer o heeven -
or wan varg - fir anidder.

Under the brow

where you see sunrise breaking over the Bard
and the sun moving round past Helliness;

where there's no better stone for building,
and plenty close to hand;

where stakes can be driven deep
in a green land. But we move on:

leave one measure of heaven -
or one drudgery - for another.

title: Fladdabister, Cunningsburgh
derivation: Fladdabister - ON flata (Shetland - flada) - a plain; bólstaðr (Shetland - busta, bister) - home, farm (Jakobsen, p26-7 & p40)
poem:
When hit wis lichtsome

Sic a dose o fock oot wirkin da simmer rigs,
moarnin ta nicht: syes flashin, skurtfoos o coarn,
tattie-haepin; caain da hill, rooin; salistin a meenit
ta draa braeth. Bairns, barefit, rinnin oot an in.

In winter, dry flagged flörs, fires wi reestin tees abön;
sheep inbye, kye i da byres, hens neebin apö da bauk.
Tattie höls lipperin anunder fat skrews. Aathin trig
an battened doon. An fokk yarnin inta da smaa ooers.

When times were cheerful

So many people outside working the summer fields,
morning to night: sythes flashing, armfuls of oats,
potato-heaping; rounding-up sheep, shearing; resting briefy
to draw breath. Children, barefoot, running out and in.

In winter, dry flagged floors, fires with legs of lamb curing above;
sheep in from the hill, cows in byres, hens dozing on the rafter.
Potato stores full under fat corn-stacks. Everything tidy
and battened down. And folk telling stories into the small hours.

title: Burraland, Sandwick
derivation: Burraland - borg O.N. a fort (broch in Shetland) (Jakobsen, p28)
poem:
Naethin is firivver

Whin you bigg here, aside a broch,
wi steyn laek skelfs shaaved aesy fae da banks,
you tink sic coarnersteyns 'll hadd fir generations.

Whin you dell here, saa bere an coarn,
maa an stook it, wi sun haet apön your back,
an bairns wippin baands, you tink hit's fir ivver.

Whin Midder lifts a jug o blaand fae da gligg,
brings hit tae ta rig ta slokk your trist,
fir a peerie while, your wirries faa awa.

Nothing is forever

When you build here, beside a broch,
with slithers of stone shaved easily from the cliffs,
you think such cornerstones will hold for generations.

When you dig here, sow barley and oats,
mow and stack it, with sun hot on your back,
and children making straw twists, you think it's for ever.

When Mother lifts a jug of whey from the wall-cavity,
brings it to the field to quench your thirst,
for a moment, your worries subside.

title: Clumlie, Dunrossness
derivation: Clumli - site of a former church dedicated to St Columba (Jakobsen, p174)
poem:
Circles an squares

Dis steyn can bigg you a circle:
a broch wi tick waas ta staand firivver;
a kiln ta set a fire ta dry coarn or bere;
a waal fir spring watter;
a crub fir winterin your kale;
punds an crös ta gadder sheep;
quern steyns, mill steyns, skroo-steids.

Dis steyn can bigg you straight an square:
a hoose, a barn, a byre, a yard dyk;
a window, a door; a hearth, a braa new porch.
Maybe a kirk, an a steyn ta mark a grave.

Circles and squares

This stone can build a circle for you:
a broch with thick walls to stand forever;
a kiln ta set a fire to dry oats or barley;
a well for spring water;
an enclosure for wintering your kale;
pounds an folds to gather sheep;
quern stones, mill stones, foundations for stacks.

This stone can build straight and square for you:
a house, a barn, a byre, a yard wall;
a window, a door, a hearth, a fine new porch.
Maybe a church, and a stone to mark a grave.

title: Linga, Parish of Tingwall
derivation: Linga - ON lyng-øy - heather island ('øy' abbreviated to 'a' in Shaetlan (Jakobsen, p144 & p122)
poem:
Da Peerie Isles

Hunkered anunder da broo - an wi Hildasay
bi wast - de'r a grain o shalter, but da wind
fae da nort comes wheepin troo.
De'r nae richt place fir a noost
or a beach ta dry wir catch.

We hae tree infants böried at Papil noo.
Wir fock is laevin fir Trondra, Burra, even Canada.
But on a boannie day, we aa tink lang fir Linga.
Foo muckle waar ir we pooed fae dat ebb,
greened up da toon, sweetened da yard?

The Little Isles

Hunkered under the brow - and with Hildasay
to the west - there's a little shelter, but the wind
from the north comes whipping through.
There's no good place for a boat shelter
or a beach to dry our catch.

We have three infants buried at Papil now.
Our relatives are leaving for Trondra, Burra, even Canada.
But on a fine day, we all miss Linga.
How much seaweed have we pulled from that shore,
greened up the field, sweetened the yard?
